awd_titl_txt: Elements: Software: The Integrated Geoscience Observatory (InGeO)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the development of the Integrated Geoscience Observatory (InGeO). InGeO is an online platform that integrates data and associated software tools contributed by researchers into a unified toolset to enable studying the convergent, systems science. Complex processes in the Sun-Earth system affect the habitability of earth. As technological progress continues, our society also becomes increasingly vulnerable to the disruptions introduced by these complex processes. Study of the Sun-Earth system is traditionally broken-up into separate geoscience disciplines, typically focusing on a specific region of the system. However, often the interaction between several regions end up significantly affecting terrestrial systems. For example, a chain of processes occurring between the Sun, magnetosphere, and ionosphere often result in loss of GPS signal that severely affects all the communication/navigation and infrastructure that depends on this technology. To broach the larger question of the interaction of the subsystems studied by the separate communities, it is necessary to overcome the barriers of communication posed by different observational instruments, software tools for interpreting data, and modeling methods.

To promote systems science, InGeO creates an integrated package of software tools specifically designed to help researchers find and integrate diverse observational data and distributes this toolkit to the community in the most flexible way possible. Building on the pilot project supported by the NSF EarthCube program, the specific features of the toolkit include: (a) linking diverse data sets from multiple observational data repositories; (b) using these data within a shareable computing environment, complete with a full selection of standard numerical and data-processing tools; and  (c) enabling an ever growing assortment of targeted, user-contributed tools, such as assimilative models or interpolation methods. The toolkit can be accessed and used either through a web-based computing environment or by downloading Docker containers for local installation, with a nearly seamless transition between the two. The toolkit is open-source and ensures credit attribution to data and software contributors, and the InGeO team works with members of scientific community (especially students and early career researchers) to improve the toolkit and build a sustainable, more connected user-base.

This award by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the Cross-Cutting Activities Program within the NSF Directorate for Geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Integrated Geoscience Observatory (InGeO) project was initiated to improve collaboration among the scientists studying the earth's space environment, or geospace, and create a software solution to enable computationally reproducible results toward those goals. The InGeO project has developed an open-source Reproducible Software Environment (Resen) platform that currently serves the geospace community’s need to access and analyze various ground- and space-based data from NSF and NASA sources, and provides some physics-based and empirical models. The Resen platform can be used on our server as an online interface and as a downloadable version.

One of the goals of this grant was to do significant user outreach for InGeO and Resen. While we cannot track this exactly, various use and download statistics for both versions indicate that the Resen software currently has approximately 60-150 users who span the US and international communities. The InGeO project team also successfully brought topics of computational reproducibility, the required data and software infrastructure, and best practices to the attention of the geospace community.

Intellectual Merit

1.   Research reproducibility is a cornerstone for scientific advance. By bringing a renewed focus on reproducibility, the InGeO project is generating community conversations and potential improvements to how research is done by and for the geospace community.

2.   The Resen software enables users to access data and software, conduct analyses, publish results, and share the results with the research community through a single open-source platform, without spending countless hours on figuring out the installation, configuration, and usage of various software tools and dependency trees. The results produced through Resen follow the gold-standard for computational reproducibility by incorporating the computing environment into the published result extending the reproducibility of results beyond the lifecycles of software tools used.

Broader Impact

1.   The InGeO team has developed and included several tutorials for users at all stages to learn Python, JupyterLab, and various Python packages in Resen. This benefits students and early-career researchers, and also encourages mid-career researchers to start exploring these tools, which are becoming increasingly popular for scientific research.

2.   The InGeO team has painstakingly documented the Resen software for both users and developers, so that other research communities can adapt this model. Similarly, the documentation allows academics to adapt Resen to aid in classroom or remote teaching. The adaptability and availability of the GPL v3.0 license makes Resen useful beyond the geospace community, and several developers are tracking Resen development on GitHub for this purpose.

3.   The InGeO team has prepared several webinars, resource pages, and white papers that are available on the InGeO project website and has posted some public-facing webinars on YouTube.
